word.entryDescription: a big shop selling lots of things, especially food and things for the house
word.entryExample: Mum usually goes shopping in the big supermarket.

word.entryDescription: to look after and control
word.entryExample: We need a lifeguard to supervise swimmers in our pool.

word.entryDescription: to approve of and often encourage or help somebody or something because you want them to be successful
word.entryExample: The best way to support local shops and restaurants is to use them.

word.entryDescription: a sport or activity in which you ride on waves using a special board
word.entryExample: Shall we go surfing in the sea?

word.entryDescription: a sudden increase and move forward of water
word.entryExample: Many people know about hurricanes and tornadoes even though it's less well-known that storm surges cause 90% of deaths.
Anna's brother had knee surgery.

word.entryDescription: something unexpected that happens
word.entryExample: Let's have a surprise party for Sam this year!

word.entryDescription: reacting to something unexpected
word.entryExample: She put her hand in front of her mouth because she was surprised by the news.

word.entryDescription: unexpected; unusual
word.entryExample: The message he received was very surprising.

word.entryDescription: near or around someone or something
word.entryExample: They explored the surrounding countryside and discovered beautiful spots.

word.entryDescription: the activity of asking a lot of people specific questions in order to find out what they think, how they behave, etc
word.entryExample: What's the second question in the school dinner survey, William?

word.entryDescription: to stay alive in a difficult situation
word.entryExample: This man and his family survived in a tree for seven days.

word.entryDescription: a cold Japanese dish consisting of small cakes of rice and usually thin slices of raw fish
word.entryExample: Would your grandparents have sushi for lunch?

word.entryDescription: somebody who is thought likely to have committed a crime or done something wrong
word.entryExample: If a suspect is guilty, he might have to go to prison.

word.entryDescription: to think that something is likely or that someone is guilty
word.entryExample: He was briefly suspected of being involved in the crime, but he wasn't arrested because he had an alibi.

word.entryDescription: (of living) living in a way that does not damage the environment
word.entryExample: I recycle a lot, because I believe in sustainable living.

word.entryDescription: a large white bird with a rounded yellow and black beak that lives on rivers and lakes
word.entryExample: Just walk through Regent's Park, past the lake where there are lots of ducks and swans swimming.

word.entryDescription: to go somewhere as a large uncontrolled crowd
word.entryExample: A swarm of journalists encircled the car with the famous rock singer.

word.entryDescription: very large, long and thin area of something, especially land
word.entryExample: Brownfield building will save some land, but swathes of countryside will still disappear.

word.entryDescription: to have drops of sweat on the surface of your skin, for example when you are hot, ill/sick or afraid
word.entryExample: You sweat a lot when you run and lose a lot of water.

word.entryDescription: liquid that comes out of the skin when you are hot, ill/sick or afraid
word.entryExample: I was sitting in the same school hall that I'd sat in so many times, with its familiar smell of cleaning fluid and stale sweat.

word.entryDescription: a thick item of casual clothing with long sleeves worn on the upper body
word.entryExample: He usually wears jeans and a hooded sweatshirt.

word.entryDescription: covered in sweat
word.entryExample: My palms were so sweaty that I didn't know if I'd even be able to hold my violin, let alone play it.

word.entryDescription: having a taste like sugar
word.entryExample: I really love the taste of sweet food, like cakes and biscuits.

word.entryDescription: small sweet pieces of food made from sugar or chocolate
word.entryExample: Chocolate and sweets, on a pizza? That sounds horrible!

word.entryDescription: an area of someone's body that is larger than normal, because of illness or injury
word.entryExample: I took off my boots and was horrified to see swellings on both my ankles.

word.entryDescription: to move through water using your arms and legs
word.entryExample: I can't swim very well.

word.entryDescription: = swimsuit (a costume you wear when you go swimming)
word.entryExample: Don't forget to pack your swimming suit! There's a swimming pool in the hotel.

word.entryDescription: a place in a town for swimming
word.entryExample: I swim at the swimming pool every Saturday.

word.entryDescription: a costume you wear when you go swimming
word.entryExample: You have to wear a swimsuit on a pool.

word.entryDescription: to turn off a machine, light, etc using a button or switch
word.entryExample: Remember to switch off your computer every night.

word.entryDescription: to turn on a machine, light, etc using a button or switch
word.entryExample: I have to switch on the printer to print out my statement.

word.entryDescription: to represent something; to be a symbol of something
word.entryExample: What do these masks symbolise?

word.entryDescription: to feel sorry for someone; to show that you understand somebody's problems
word.entryExample: She said she sympathized with me but didn't know how to help.

word.entryDescription: being sorry for someone who is in a bad situation
word.entryExample: I have a lot of sympathy for Tom; he had to bring up the children on his own.

word.entryDescription: a change in the body or mind or a feeling caused by an illness
word.entryExample: What are the symptoms of rabies?

word.entryDescription: a piece of clothing with short sleeves you wear over the top half of your body
word.entryExample: Tim has a new T-shirt.

word.entryDescription: a piece of furniture with legs and a wide flat top we use to put things
word.entryExample: We sit at the table and have lunch.

word.entryDescription: a game played on a large table in which you use small round bats to hit a small ball over a low net
word.entryExample: We play table tennis at lunchtime.

word.entryDescription: a small computer that has a large touch screen and is easy to carry
word.entryExample: Grandad doesn't like the computer as much as the tablet.

word.entryDescription: a small hard piece of medicine which you swallow
word.entryExample: Take two tablets after meals.

word.entryDescription: to attempt to deal with something difficult, e.g. crime
word.entryExample: The police and other public services can't tackle crime alone.

word.entryDescription: careful not to embarrass or upset somebody
word.entryExample: Anna says it is important to be tactful when customers ask for an opinion.

word.entryDescription: the part of an animal's body that joins onto the bottom of its back
word.entryExample: Cats have long tails.

word.entryDescription: to accept something that someone gives you
word.entryExample: This present is for you – please take it!

word.entryDescription: to start to employ someone
word.entryExample: He's going to try to persuade the people at the Ritz to take him on.

word.entryDescription: (of food or drink) to buy it and eat/drink it away from the place where it's made
word.entryExample: There are also many cafés and restaurants across the city where you can eat in or take away food and drink.

word.entryDescription: to return something to a place or a person, often to the shop where you bought something because it is damaged or unsuitable
word.entryExample: Oh no – this necklace is broken. I think I'll have to take it back.

word.entryDescription: to look after someone or something
word.entryExample: Take care of your body. Exercise is really important.

word.entryDescription: to do physical activities in order to be stronger and remain healthy
word.entryExample: Most people need to take more exercise.
